title: Movie Review: High Life - Hit & Run :
content:
Sometimes, I approach a movie review with a preexisting bias. I admit it. I haven't seen it yet, but I want High Life to be a great movie. I want to believe!
I appreciate the accusation that it's boring, but Solaris (1972) was like that. Part of it was that Solaris clocked in at around two hours and 45 minutes. Still, its themes and imagery haunted me long after I saw it--and isn't that the mark of a great science fiction film? High Life clocks in at under two hours. I can take that if there's a pay off.
In regards to the physics acting unlike they would in space, could that possibly be a literary effect, say, perhaps, dramatic irony? I haven't seen the film. I want to believe! Is the director telling us that the universal principles we're observing in space work the same way on earth?
I have a huge TV, a Roku box, the kanopy app, and easy access to all the best movies ever made. The Criterion collection even has their own app now. I want a reason to go to the theater again, and I was hoping High Life would be it.

title: Movie Review: High Life - Hit & Run :
content: Argh. It sounds like it might have been a good movie, but missed the mark, somehow. I'm sure I'll eventually end up watching it, though. I liked Solaris, both the 70s version and the newer version with George Clooney. I dunno, I guess I just want more than light flares and explosions in my scifi movies.
